hawaiian_text: 'Ī aku 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Ua 'ike au, he kanaka nui nō 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o, a ua hele aku nei ma Ko'olau, a 'o wau he inoa nona." 'Ī mai lākou: "'A'ole, 'o 'oe nō, pela ko makou lohe, no laila, e make ana 'oe iā mākou, 'a'ole 'oe e ola." 'Ī aku 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Ho'i aku ho'i hā kākou i lalo e hakakā ai." A hiki lākou i lalo, e hao aku ana 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o, pau loa i ka make, a koe aku ho'okahi kanaka, 'o ia ka i holo aku ā loa'a 'o 'Ama'u ma Waikīkī, 'ōlelo akula ia i ka make o lākou a pau loa, a koe ia i 'āha'ilono e lohe ai 'o 'Ama'u.
qwen3-235b-a22b-think-parser-fireworks_t: "Then said Nāmakaokapāo'o: 'I know, I am indeed a great man, Nāmakaokapāo'o has indeed gone to Ko'olau, and my name belongs to that place.' They said to him: 'No, you are the one we heard of, and therefore you will die by us, you shall not live.' Said Nāmakaokapāo'o: 'Let us indeed go down again to converse.' And when they arrived below, Nāmakaokapāoōo destroyed them entirely, and only one man escaped who ran away and found refuge at 'Āma'u in Waikīkī, proclaiming the deaths of them all, and was present at the council for 'Āma'u to hear."
qwen3-235b-a22b-think-parser-fireworks_c: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation>
"Then said Nāmakaokapāo'o: 'I know, I am indeed a great man, Nāmakaokapāo'o has indeed gone to Ko'olau, and my name belongs to that place.' They said to him: 'No, you are the one we heard of, and therefore you will die by us, you shall not live.' Said Nāmakaokapāo'o: 'Let us indeed go down again to converse.' And when they arrived below, Nāmakaokapāoōo destroyed them entirely, and only one man escaped who ran away and found refuge at 'Āma'u in Waikīkī, proclaiming the deaths of them all, and was present at the council for 'Āma'u to hear."
</translation>

<commentary>
**Paragraph 13:** • This passage demonstrates the hero's self-identification with the Ko'olau region, literally claiming his name belongs to that place, which reflects a deep spiritual and geographical connection in Hawaiian thought; – His statement "Ua 'ike au" (I have knowledge) indicates a state of kāmaunu (spiritual awakening) or kuleana (responsibility) that comes with proven strength; – "He kanaka nui nō" (a great man indeed) reinforces his status as a kua'ā (superhuman figure) in the Polynesian tradition of māhu as supernatural beings. 

• The antagonists identify Nāmakaokapāo'o as their foretold challenger ("pela ko makou lohe"), referencing a propehcy motif common in kūʻauhau (oral histories), where fate is determined by divine knowledge; – The threat "'e make ana 'oe iā mākou'" (you will die by us) suggests they see themselves as instruments of the gods, acting under divine imperative.

• The descent to the lower area to speak ("ho'i aku ho'i hā kākou i lalo e hakakā ai") follows the Hawaiian tradition of resolving conflict through dialogue first, even between foes; – The battle that ensues (lākou ma lalo) takes place in an ambiguous time and space, typical of moʻolelo that often shift between pō and ao (spiritual and physical realms). 

• The complete destruction of his adversaries ("pau loa i ka make") and sole survivor create a narrative structure seen in creation myths, where one escapes to spread ke kaumaha (word of loss) – The name 'Āma'u (ascend and walk) in Waikīkī (spouting waters) likely represents a 'āha (council) site with water-based kānāwai (laws); the survivor bringing news there follows Hawaiian kōrero (wisdom) that water carries knowledge.
</commentary>
reference_translation: Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "I know. Nāmakaokapāo'o is a really big guy. He went to Ko'olau. I'm named after him." The soldiers said, "No, it's you. That's what we heard. So, we're going to kill you. You won't survive." Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "Well, let's go down and fight." When they got down, Nāmakaokapāo'o went to work and killed them all except one man, who ran off and reached 'Ama'u in Waikīkī. He told him about the how they were all killed except for one runner to go and tell 'Ama'u about it.
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14** • From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of Christianity's defeat over the 'Ai Kapu, with Nāmakaokapāo'o representing progressive Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his mother, Pōka'ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians' futile attempts to hold onto 'Ai Kapu culture.
